intent: Endpoint and cloud security fundamentals for defensive posture, hardening, and risk reasoning.

sections.name: Endpoint Security Fundamentals
sections.summary: Endpoints (laptops, servers, mobile devices) are common initial access points and require layered protection.
principles: Use endpoint detection and response (EDR) or equivalent monitoring.
Enforce automatic OS and application updates.
riskPatterns: Unpatched software exploited via known vulnerabilities.
Credential theft through malware or phishing.
Lateral movement from a compromised workstation.

sections.name: Endpoint Hardening Controls
sections.summary: Configuration standards reduce attack surface and privilege misuse.
controls: Enforce strong password policies and MFA.
Restrict macro execution and script abuse.

sections.name: Cloud Shared Responsibility Model
sections.summary: Cloud providers secure the infrastructure; customers secure their configurations, identities, and data.
coreIdeas: Understand IaaS vs PaaS vs SaaS responsibility differences.
Misconfiguration is a major cloud breach driver.
Identity is the new perimeter in cloud environments.

sections.name: Cloud Identity & Access Governance
sections.summary: Cloud compromise often begins with credential misuse or privilege escalation.
principles: Use MFA for all privileged accounts.
Audit and reduce overly permissive IAM policies.
riskPatterns: Exposed API keys in public repositories.

sections.name: Cloud Network Segmentation
sections.summary: Segmentation limits blast radius when compromise occurs.
controls: Use private subnets for sensitive workloads.
Limit inbound exposure to only required ports.
Implement firewall rules and security groups.
Log and monitor network flow data.

sections.name: Container & Runtime Security
sections.summary: Containers require image integrity, runtime monitoring, and minimal privileges.

sections.name: Cloud Logging & Monitoring
sections.summary: Visibility into cloud events is essential for detecting misuse and breach indicators.
keyIdeas: Enable audit logs for all accounts.
Centralize logs into a secure location.
Alert on privilege escalation and policy changes.
Monitor failed login attempts and anomalous API calls.
